thread.title: Labour dominate in Sunderland as Corbyn defies expectations in General Election 2017

author: Sean Seddon
title: Labour dominate in Sunderland as Corbyn defies expectations in General Election 2017
text:
News Labour dominate in Sunderland as Corbyn defies expectations in General Election 2017 Sunderland lost its crown for returning the first result on a night which went well for Labour on Wearside Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Labour has retained its iron grip on Wearside retaining all three seats. 
What proved to be a good night for the party, in Sunderland at least, started with Bridget Phillipson being re-elected as MP for Houghton and Sunderland South . 
Turnout was up across the area but Sunderland couldn’t extend its run of getting the first vote out to a seventh general election - that dubious honour was clinched in Newcastle Central. 
The Conservative vote stood up across the area but UKIP have been all but wiped out in the region that has become so strongly associated with Brexit. 
Wearside has grown used to having the eyes of the world’s media on it in recent years but voters weren’t in the mood to put on a show, opting for the status quo. 
Ms Phillipson received 24,665 votes on a turnout of 61%, up from 55.1% in 2015. 
She told the crowd at Silksworth Community Pool, Tennis and Wellness Centre: “ The Labour Party was founded to secure political power for communities like ours. 
“We still believe the Government can be a force for good.” Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now 
Then came Sunderland Central , the seat which Labour might have been most worried about in the event of a big swing to the Tories. 
In the end, Julie Elliott dispatched of her Conservative challenger with relative ease, racking up 25,056 votes on a 62.1% turnout, up from 57% in 2015. 
She said: “I spoke to more than 6,000 people this campaign, sometimes having difficult conversations and listening carefully and, the promises I have given to you, I will keep.” 
Then Sharon Hodgson capped it off with a similarly assured performance in Washington and Sunderland West , receiving 24,639 votes on a 60.4% turnout, up from 54.6%. 
She laced into Theresa May, saying this election “could prove to be her undoing”. 
But all three saw their majorities slightly reduced: Elliott’s by 1,182 votes; Phillipson’s by 597; and Hodgson’s by 217. 
However, that will be of little concern on a night which saw the party defy conventional wisdom and perform relatively strongly across the UK. 
The Conservatives picked up an extra 15,164 votes compared to the 2015 election but that wasn’t enough to remotely worry Labour. 
The UKIP vote across Wearside completely collapsed - across the three seats, their vote count has gone from 23,598 to 7,349 in just two years. 
Sunderland’s three female MPs have defied any political expectations that formed after the referendum on membership of the European Union. 
Many initially thought this would be ‘the Brexit election’ and see areas which voted Leave flock to the Conservatives. 
That hasn’t materialised and the old tribal pull the party still exerts in the North East has trumped any swing towards a more vociferously pro-Brexit party. Read More Washington and Sunderland West - Labour HOLD
